list_definition.definition: a narrow strip of leather, cloth, or other material, eg with a buckle for fastening something (eg a suitcase, wristwatch etc) or by which to hold, hang or support something (eg a camera, rucksack etc)
a short looped strip of leather etc, hanging from the roof of a train, by which a standing passenger can support himself/herself.
to beat (eg a schoolchild) on the hand with a leather strap

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He was strapped for being rude to the teacher.

list_definition.definition: to fasten with a strap etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The two pieces of luggage were strapped together
He strapped on his new watch.

list_ex_of_english: The straps that bind it on us seem inclined to cut into our flesh more and more.
I support the argument that safety straps should be improved.
He more or less told them to pull themselves up by their boot straps.
Often, they are already in labour, strapped to a drip, and in severe pain.
If the council rejects an application, however, the cost of an appeal is a considerable burden for an authority that is strapped for cash.
However, the universities are plainly in a difficult position because they are strapped for cash—they ain't got any.
However, the new clause covers only belts, straps and other instruments.
The two-thirds of the world's population who at present are the dispossessed will be able to raise themselves up only by their own shoe-straps.
